head.title: A Weeping Willow In the Orchard

hedline.hl1: A Weeping Willow In the Orchard

abstract.p: V L Higgins letter requests further information on June 18 article about weeping willow growing in Bellamy-Ferriday estate garden in Bethlehem, Conn; editor's note; photo (S)

block.p: I would appreciate further details about the following statement from the article entitled ''A 1920's Estate Garden Is Carefully Restored'' (June 18): ''In other notes she left, Caroline Ferriday identified ancestry of a weeping willow in the orchard. The tree came from cutting of willow growing on Isle of Elba where Napoleon lived.''

An 1896 monograph (Charlotte Malvina Bulkley, Southport, ''Reminiscences of the Past'') identifies a willow in Southport as grown from a tree ''planted on Buonaparte's grave on the island of St. Helena [sic], where he died in 1821. Mr. Joseph Sheffield, of New Haven, [founder of Sheffield Scientific School at Yale], obtained several slips, on his last trip abroad, giving the above to his sister who then owned the property.''
The ''Napoleon willow'' on Willow Street in Southport was blown down in a storm in 1901, according to an article printed on January 3, 1931 in the Fairfield News.
